reviewText: This movie is almost nostalgic now with the 70s clothes and so dated tech. While it has a very similar Gene Roddenberry feel to Genesis II the simple plot, again based on the same message as Genesis II of give peace a chance, is not enough to sustain this film this far down the road.  In another parallel both enjoy the performances of Mariette Hartley. The DVD is a very good transfer. So good in fact the strings clearly visible in many of the weightless scenes.
summary: So as a look back into the 70s view of the future it scores well but as ageless sci-fi not so well.

reviewText: I had only the foggiest of memories of this film and had scoured the internet for many years in the hopes someone had a copy available. The closest I came was running into a video vulture - one of those toadies who creep along the dark underbelly of the collectibles world, preying on fans to earn coin. He wanted $50 for a middling VHS copy I understood was taken from a tv broadcast back in the 1980s. <smh>So I am very thankful to Warner Bros for finally realizing that there's cash flow to be had from obscure movies - without forcing fans to drop trow and lube up. Their Archive Collection has put a major dent in the business of these slimebags. Nice.What surprised me: This tv movie was in color. Even though this has happened to me previously, I was caught off-guard; my memory had obscured over time and I didn't realize the reason I recall this in black and white was I watched it on a small portable tv - a black & white tv. The opening scene with it's shocking technicolor blast really threw me for a loop.Sadly, what didn't surprise me was how lousy this made-for-tv movie actually is; time had not soften or eased the ridiculously superficial story.Filmed in 1971, with the nation fascinated with the Apollo Program and anything space related, comes this pseudo-political thriller about an orbiting space station. Said station unbelievably convinces the people who paid for it - taxpayers - that they were an independent country, no longer subject to the rules or laws of anyone but themselves. Right. That would work I'm sure. Won't spend any more energy explaining the two or three dozen reasons why this is absurd. Suffice to say, from the opening sequence the pubescent plot essentially becomes a "lesson" for us earthbound knuckle-draggers. These space denizens are going to teach us the "right" way to live.Awesome, a proto-James Cameron flick. Just what I needed.Been patronized before by filmmakers who are hellbent on showing us lemmings the correct way of living, but this really stands out as cheap political grandstanding masking itself as entertainment. Did I mention James Cameron already?Worse, it depicts a truly chauvinistic view of women. According to the filmmakers:  They're illogical, emotionally unstable, and stupid. If I were a woman - I'd burn the master copy.Completely worthless save for the interesting special effects and seeing beautiful Mariette Hartley in her prime. Oddly enough, I'm still pleased I purchased the disc. It was worth it to finally scratch that itch at a reasonable price and simultaneously give a virtual bird to those parasitic dealers.
